Now, you look at the high concentration of protons (H+) in the intermembrane space. The electrical potential across that membrane is equivalent to a lightning bolt (~100-300 million volts). 

"A membrane potential of 150 mV across the 5-nanometer membrane gives a field strength of 30 million volts per meter ‚Äî equivalent to a bolt of lightning."

If you've ever seen or heard a lightning bolt before, it's extremely powerful, terrifying & beautiful all at the same time. 

We have ~37 trillion of these mitochondria in our bodies, with multiple ETC compartments per mitochondrion (~2000-10,000). All harnessing the energy of mini lightning bolts to make use of it for our biology‚Äîin the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). How bloody awesome is that.

And this isn't even taking into account other very important bioenergetic domains like water, collagen/fascia, melanin, DHA/lipids, aromatic amino acids & other semiconductive proteins.

Bioenergetics, at its core‚Äîis the stunning interplay of biochemical/biophysical principles & molecular machinery, converting electrical energy into vital chemical energy (& vice versa) to fuel life as we know it.

quotedObject.fullText:
Any electromagnetic wave carries not only energy but also momentum, which is a characteristic property of all objects in motion. The existence of this momentum becomes evident with the phenomenon called ‚Äúradiation pressure‚Äù in which a light beam transfers its momentum to an absorbing or scattering object, generating a mechanical pressure on it. Light exerts pressure on objects. Light may also carry angular momentum, which is a property of all objects in rotational motion. A light beam can be rotating around its own axis while it propagates forward, and the existence of this angular momentum is evidenced when an optical torque is induced to a small absorbing or scattering particle that receives this transfer of angular momentum during the interaction. The angular momentum of light expresses the amount of dynamical rotation present in its electromagnetic field. A light beam can be rotating, or ‚Äúspinning,¬†twisting‚Äù around its own axis, while propagating forward. Photons with a twisted phase front can carry a discrete, unbounded¬†amount of orbital angular momentum (OAM). The large number of states allows for¬†complex types of entanglement that could resist decoherence in challenging environments.

As explained in this article, the more orbital angular momentum states involved, each with different amounts of twist, the more data researchers can pack into a hologram. This does not only pack more data into holograms, but it also increases the diversity of twists used to record the data, boosting security since a person needs to know or guess how the light that recorded it was twisted, in order to read the information carried by it. For a hologram relying on two types of twist, you would have to pick the right combination of the twists from about 80 possibilities to decode the data. Considering the combinations of seven distinct twists, this leads to millions of possibilities, which should be enough to ensure a quantum holographic encryption system. https://t.co/aAnOaKSOV7

quotedObject.fullText:
The undeniable evidence that your mitochondria are light-sensing organelles which use the sun‚Äôs full spectrum for energy production

Here‚Äôs what will put those who speak ill of the sun to shame

Let‚Äôs start with the basics

Your body evolved to be under the sun‚Äôs full light spectrum, which is why every aspect of it is designed to sense and use light 

How can I prove this? 

Because we have chromophores all over the exterior and interior of our bodies

Chromophores are molecules or parts of molecules responsible for the color of compounds

They are typically the parts of a molecule that absorb visible light or ultraviolet light, leading to electronic transitions

When a chromophore absorbs light, it moves to an excited state, and the energy associated with this transition often falls within the visible spectrum, which is why we perceive color

So, how does this tie into the mitochondria? 

Well, each mitochondrion in your body contains a series of complexes which are designed to transfer electrons through redox reactions to produce energy (ATP) 

This chain of complexes is what we call the electron transport chain, and it‚Äôs found within the inner mitochondrial membrane 

Mitochondria are the lifeblood of each cell, hence they make all the difference between health and disease, life and death

It ties in perfectly because of this fact: 

The entire electron transport chain is LOADED with chromophores which are critical to the function of these complexes

Now here‚Äôs where it gets fun

I told you that your mitochondria are light-sensing organelles

Now here‚Äôs why 

‚ö°Ô∏è Complex I (NADH:Ubiquinone Oxidoreductase)

‚Ä¢ Flavin Mononucleotide (FMN): Absorbs light at around 370 nm (UV) and 450 nm (blue light)

‚Ä¢ Iron-Sulfur Clusters: These clusters have broad absorption, typically in the 400-600 nm range, but they don‚Äôt have distinct peaks like other chromophores

‚ö°Ô∏è Complex II (Succinate:Ubiquinone Oxidoreductase)

‚Ä¢ Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD): Absorbs at around 370 nm (UV) and 450 nm (blue light)

‚Ä¢ Iron-Sulfur Clusters: Similar to Complex I, absorption is broad and typically in the 400-600 nm range

‚ö°Ô∏è Complex III (Cytochrome bc1 Complex)

‚Ä¢ Cytochrome b:

- bL (low potential form): Absorbs at around 563 nm (yellow-green)

- bH (high potential form): Absorbs at around 566 nm (yellow-green) 

‚Ä¢ Cytochrome c1: Absorbs at around 552 nm

‚Ä¢ Rieske Iron-Sulfur Protein (2Fe-2S cluster): Absorption is broad, typically between 400-500 nm

‚ö°Ô∏è Complex IV (Cytochrome c Oxidase)

‚Ä¢ Cytochrome a: Absorbs at ~ 605 nm

‚Ä¢ Cytochrome a3: Absorbs at ~ 655 nm

Both orange and red light absorbed here

‚Ä¢ Copper Centers (CuA and CuB): These centers absorb broadly in the visible region, but their exact absorption properties are less defined than the heme chromophores

‚ö°Ô∏è Additional Chromophores in the ETC

Ubiquinone (Coenzyme Q): Ubiquinone itself is not strongly absorbing in the visible spectrum but does have weak absorption peaks in the UV range, around 275-290 nm

Biophoton emission right there

‚ö°Ô∏è Cytochrome c (Mobile Carrier)

Cytochrome c has an absorption wavelength of ~ 550 nm (in reduced form)

Now here‚Äôs the million dollar question 

Why does the entire electron transport chain sense various wavelengths of light from the sun at extreme precision? 

I want to see the look on every physician, dermatologist, and ophthalmologist‚Äôs face when they‚Äôre shown this information 

The overall absorption range of the chromophores within the electron transport chain is between ~ 200 nm to ~ 900 nm

From extremely low-frequency UV light (biophotons) to NIR light 

Any argument against sunlight exposure or the use of sunglasses, sunscreen, sun-avoidance is hereby deemed as retarded knowing this information 

This is especially the case because mitochondria control the health of every cell and are found everywhere in the body

I rest my case

quotedObject.fullText:
How Red Light makes ATP in mitochondria 
(Why sunrise is so important)

Step 1: The cytochrome c oxidase (CCO) enzyme absorbs red light photons

Step 2: Red light photons excite the Cu and heme groups (heme a and heme a3) within the CCO enzyme in subunits I and II.

Step 3: This excitation causes a change in the CCO enzyme, increasing its affinity for oxygen (O2)

Step 4: With increased O2 binding, the enzyme's catalytic activity rises. 

Leading to more efficient transfer of electrons and pumping of protons (4H+) across the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Step 5: This increased proton gradient drives ATP synthase to produce more ATP -> Increasing cellular energy levels.

Step 6: The enhanced CCO activity reduces nitric oxide (NO) levels, which helps with vasodilation and blood flow.

How Red Light Interacts with the a3-CuB center within the Cytochrome c Oxidase Enzyme

One of the copper centers is the binuclear a3-CuB center 

Its formed by the heme a3 iron and a copper ion (CuB).

During the catalytic cycle of CCO...

This center serves as the active site where oxygen binds and gets reduced to water by accepting four electrons.

During photobiomodulation with red/near-infrared light...

These wavelengths are absorbed by the metal centers in CCO, particularly the a3-CuB center.

Light absorption is thought to cause photodissociation of nitric oxide (NO) from the a3-CuB center. 

NO can inhibit CCO activity by binding to this center.

Removal of NO from the a3-CuB center by light absorption:

Restores AND enhances CCO's catalytic activity!

That allows for more efficient oxygen reduction and electron transport.

So red light....

Increases CCO activity, 

Leading to greater proton pumping across the mitochondrial membrane...

Increasing the proton gradient that drives ATP synthesis.

About Cytochrome C Oxidase 

Cytochrome c oxidase (CCO) is a large transmembrane protein complex located in the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

It is the terminal enzyme of the electron transport chain and contains several metal cofactors, including two heme groups and two copper centers

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a series of protein complexes in the inner mitochondrial membrane 

That transfers electrons from donors like NADH and FADH2 to the final acceptor, oxygen (O2).

It receives electrons from the mobile carrier cytochrome c and transfers them to oxygen, reducing it to water. 

This redox reaction is coupled to proton pumping across the membrane...

Contributing to the proton gradient that drives ATP synthesis by ATP synthase. 

CCO contains metal cofactors like heme and copper centers essential for its catalytic activity and efficient oxygen reduction

That's why it is so important for the ETC and cellular respiration.

Sources: https://t.co/kU30kt5UnT

quotedObject.fullText:
Hi, here's a long list of what the mitochondria can do beyond being the powerhouse of the cell (ATP): 
 
‚Äî makes metabolic deuterium-depleted water (H2O).
‚Äî makes CO2 as a byproduct. 
‚Äî mitochondrial melatonin production, one of the most powerful antioxidants we have. 
‚Äî controls autophagy, apoptosis, mitophagy, mitochondrial biogenesis, and fusion/fission.
‚Äî controls melanogenesis via melanogenin/mitofusion 2.
‚Äî location of rate-limiting step for synthesis of all steroid/sex hormones.
‚Äî endogenous light release via biophotons & ROS/RNS for cellular communication.
‚Äî aids in control of nuclear DNA/RNA transcription/translation.
‚Äî certain molecules acting as chromophores for UV, visible, and IR light.
‚Äî urea cycle to aid in depletion of ammonia & deuterium. 
‚Äî sends signals to make glutathione, superoxide dismutase, and thioredoxin/peroxiredoxin
‚Äî heme/porphyrin synthesis.
‚Äî TCA cycle, which works as a funnel for amino acids, glucogenic metabolites, and other substrates.
‚Äî controls the cell danger response.
‚Äî fatty acid synthesis/oxidation.
‚Äî environmental sensing capabilities to help dictate circadian biology.
‚Äî thermogenesis via uncoupling proteins to aid in heat production & control proton/deuterium flux.
‚Äî control of redox factors NAD+/NADH and NADP+/NADPH
‚Äî neurotransmitter synthesis of GABA & glutamate.
‚Äî breakdown of monoamines (dopamine, noradrenaline, serotonin)
‚Äî helps breakdown certain aldehydes.
‚Äî aids in calcium (Ca2+) regulation.
‚Äî glycine cleavage system (alternate pathway for making NADH)
‚Äî synthesis of iron-sulfur clusters for efficient electron transfers within enzymes/complexes.
‚Äî recycling of nitric oxide/hydrogen sulfide.
‚Äî bile acid synthesis.
‚Äî tryptophan metabolism and NAD+ synthesis.
‚Äî CoQ10 synthesis.
‚Äî catecholamine synthesis via tyrosine hydroxylase.
‚Äî aids in control of oxygen tensions.
‚Äî cell-to-cell communication via microtubules within mitochondria & cytoskeleton.
‚Äî aids in regulation of pH of mitochondria/cytosol.

Okay can't think of anymore right now and my brain hurts.

THE SEASONAL EATING DEBATE + WHY I WILL NOT BE DRINKING OJ THIS WINTER

I don't know if i'm ready for the backlash i'm going to get from this post. We all have our own views and that is okay!

Let me first explain to how our mitochondria work. Our mitochondria are not static, they are constantly changing and morphing to suit their environment. This means that if you were to draw a diagram of the structure of the mitochondria, you would need to draw several variations because the mitochondrial structure is always rearranging itself to suit the environments in which you reside.

Why do our mitochondria do this? because your mitochondria love you and are always trying to give you abundant amounts of energy all year round. So much so that they will change their physiology to suit your needs.

So what does out mitochondria do for us?

Our mitochondria are in charge of tunnelling electrons (the things food stuff is broken down into) to create electricity inside of us (stick with me here). These electrons can come from food and these electrons can also come from our environment (for free).

So what really is the fundamental difference between fat + protein and carbohydrates. It's the light that is embedded in their electrons that are broken down and fed to the mitochondria. Carbohydrates have high energy electrons because they are stored high energy photonic light. Fat and protein are lower energy electrons because they hold within the depths of their being lower energy light. 

Within the Electron transport chain we have 4 complexes + the ATPase. Complex one is where high energy electrons are ferried into the electron transport chain (ETC) utilising NADH before moving to Complex 4 where water is made. Complex two is where low energy electrons are inserted into the ETC utilising FADH as their carrier before moving to Complex 4 where water is made. Why do we need an extra complex for high energy electrons? because we need more time to rip off and bury the light emitted from these electrons during their redox reaction at each complex due to their high energy state. Our body is very efficient and hides energy through both vibrational and light sources throughout our physiology. 

Remember how I said our mitochondria change for us? they can become coupled, or uncoupled. The can minimise complex one when it is not needed. How do our mitochondria know what form and shape they should take an any given time? Our mitochondria are constantly sensing their environment. One of the ways they do this is through light. If no UV light is present and you are cold, your mitochondria will prepare itself to ferry low energy electrons from fats, protein and not carbohydrates. You should not be eating high energy electrons when they do not naturally grow in your location for this reason. If you do, you will increase inflammation and develop leptin resistance quickly while also ruining your thyroid function before being prescribed bioidentical hormones or the likes (aspirin). 

You should not need to take supplements to support your thyroid production if you and healthy and living in alignment with your environment. Nature didn't create supplements, silly people did to cope with the silly decisions and choices they make in their life like eating imported foods and bathing under blue light. 

The way our mitochondria functions in winter time is completely different to how our mitochondria functions in the summer time. It's not just the food that goes into our mouth that controls our metabolism, it is the light we are around and also our hormones including our master hormone (leptin) (funnily enough our hormones are also controlled by light). One function is not better than the other and both are needed to break the second law of thermodynamics. 

Lets talk about the winter mitochondria.

In winter time our body feels the cold air, the low solar yield and our mitochondria change the way they are shaped to tunnel low energy electrons. This system is quantised and yolked to our environment. When we consume low energy electrons we conserve energy because we are no longer utilising complex one. Complex two is also not a proton pump and thus this means that there is less voltage in the mitochondrial inter membrane space. This lack of voltage also means that there is less ATP output per mitochondrion but an increase on heat emission per mitochondrion. This light is not wasted, it is captured by our water network to do work (this heat is utilised as a form of energy).

So again what happens when we consume imported foods such as carbohydrates in the dead of winter when no/minimal carbs grow around us? Inflammation. See the light around us is telling and preparing our body to consume food that holds electrons that are full of the same light that shines on our skin. The temperature of our environment will also help to either uncouple or couple our mitochondria to increase our thermodynamic efficiency.

What is the bedrock of all systemic dis-ease? inflammation. 

In winter time our body knows that we will have a lack of food electrons in our environment. Thus our mitochondria feels the cool air on our skin and the absence of UV light in our eyes and uncouples our mitochondria so that we make more heat internally which is emitted from our mitochondria and quite literally is a form of energy.

Drinking Orange juice 4 x a day in the dead of winter (if you live somewhere with seasonal variance) is not a good idea. This is not only true for the previous reasons mentioned but also due to the heavy deuterium content of Fruits.

Other things to consider when choosing a species and season appropriate diet: 

‚Ä¢¬†Deuterium toxicity 
‚Ä¢¬†Thyroid health 
‚Ä¢¬†Leptin resistance 
‚Ä¢¬†Natures laws 
‚Ä¢¬†Biophoton emission (does the light you consume match the light on your skin)
‚Ä¢¬†Does the person who told you to eat fruit all winter take supplements to deal with the health issues eating fruit all winter gave them? 

I am currently working with three women to realign their internal light show after they spent 6-12 months on a pro-metabolic diet and let me tell you, even though you may feel great for a period of time, it is much harder to reverse your health issues when your body starts to reject this way of eating. This way of eating is not optimal for life quality or longevity especially If you are leptin resistance to begin with which is probably the root cause of your health concerns.

quotedObject.fullText:
The electron transport chain in the mitochondria of humans, and mammals as a whole, reverses the process of photosynthesis in chloroplasts. Electrons, hydrogen (H+), and oxygen (O2) make ATP and water (H2O), extremely simply put.

Blue light (and nnEMF, both as some of the highest energy outputs) disrupts the complex enzymes of the ETC, as well as electron transfer capacity (electron leak), K+ signaling (crucial to mitochondrial water handling), ATP synthesis, thus disrupting H2O formation as end product of the ETC.

The chromophores (light sensors) that make up the ETC shift from ground, to singlet, to triplet state, which transfers electrons to O2, forming superoxide (O2‚Ä¢-) and a photosensitizer radical cation. That triplet state chromophore transfers energy to O2 to form singlet O2. The leakage of electrons interacts with O2 to form more O2‚Ä¢-. That O2‚Ä¢- receives more electrons from this leakage to form other reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxy radicals (¬∑OH), and perhydroxyl radicals (HO2¬∑).

Electron leakage from the ETC is caused by the disruption and subsequent damage to complex/cytochrome enzymes.

quotedObject.fullText:
1/3 

Mitochondria are normally protected from oxidative damage by a network of antioxidant systems which consist of superoxide dismutase, catalase, glutathione peroxidase and glutathione reductase together with a number of low molecular weight antioxidants such as Œ±-tocopherol and ubiquinol. 

These molecules are particularly effective in scavenging lipid peroxyl radicals and preventing free radical chain reactions of lipid peroxidation. 

Cumulative oxidative injuries to mitochondria, triggered by endogenous metabolic processes and/or exogenous oxidative influences, cause mitochondria to progressively become less efficient. 

As mitochondria progressively lose their functional integrity, ever-greater proportions of oxygen molecules reaching them are converted to ROS. 

So the numerous and disparate mitochondrial functions include the synthesis of most of the ATP present in the cell, apoptosis, ion homeostasis, cellular stress response, antioxidant control, redox regulation, mitophagy and the involvement in various biosynthetic pathways.       
                                                
Oxidative stress occurs when there is an imbalance between free radical production and their detoxification. 

Free radicals are unstable compounds that lead to cell destruction and chronic inflammation.

An atom or group of atoms with an unpaired electron which grabs electrons from a stable molecule are called a free radical.

This electron-grabbing is called oxidation and can set up a chain reaction, creating new free radicals and damaging important molecules along the way if not enough antioxidants are present.

Antioxidants are molecules that can donate an electron to stabilize and neutralize free radicals. 

An antioxidant can stop the free radical chain reaction in its tracks by donating an electron and then the antioxidant itself becomes a free radical. 

But antioxidants are not very reactive themselves and have processes for quick stabilization.

Free radicals are a natural byproduct of metabolic reactions and of exercise, it is normal to have low levels of free radicals in the body and with enough antioxidants present, free radicals can be kept in check.

However, too many free radicals and not enough protection from antioxidants creates a situation called oxidative stress. 

Free radical development is unavoidable, but we have adapted to them by setting up and maintaining defense mechanisms that reduce their impact. 

The body‚Äôs two major defense systems are free radical detoxifying enzymes which are responsible for protecting the insides of cells from free radical damage  and antioxidants which act both inside and outside of cells and block free radicals from stealing electrons by donating one to them.

The three major enzyme systems and the chemical reactions they catalyze are:

1. Superoxide Dismutases (SOD). 
They are essential for free radical detoxification and these enzymes either have copper (crucial), manganese or zinc as a cofactor. 

2. Catalase. 
These enzymes convert hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen and finish the detoxification process that SOD starts. This enzyme contains iron as a cofactor but since iron can be tricky, don‚Äôt simply start upping the high iron foods in order to boost catalase enzymes.

3. Glutathione Peroxidases. 
These selenium dependent enzymes also convert hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen.

Antioxidants are broadly classified as either hydrophilic (water soluble) or hydrophobic (lipid soluble), and this classification determines where they act in the body. 

Hydrophilic antioxidants act in the cytosol of cells or in extracellular fluids such as blood, hydrophobic antioxidants are largely responsible for protecting cell membranes from free radical damage. 

The body can synthesize some antioxidants, but others must be obtained from the diet.

There are two antioxidants that the body synthesizes. 
1) Glutathione, which contains a sulfur group that can donate an electron to a free radical, thereby stabilizing it.
2) Uric acid which is too high of a concentration can cause gout. 

There are many different antioxidants in food as well.

Antioxidant vitamins (Vitamin E, Vitamin C) donate their electrons to free radicals to stabilize them. 

Antioxidant phytochemicals (beta-carotene and other carotenoids) may inhibit the oxidation of lipids or donate electrons. 

Antioxidant minerals act as cofactors within complex antioxidant enzyme systems (superoxide dismutases, catalase, glutathione peroxidases described earlier) to convert free radicals to less damaging substances that can be excreted.

Cytochrome C oxidase in the mitochondrial membrane is sensitive to Sunlight.

Light in the red range (between 613.5 and 623.5‚Äänm), the far-red range (between 667.5 and 683.7‚Äänm), and two peak positions in the infrared range (750.7‚Äì772.3‚Äänm and 812.5‚Äì846.0‚Äänm have an absorption spectra in the two copper centers in cytochrome C oxidase, the CuA binuclear center and the heme A3/CuB binuclear center.

Why is this important? All energy made in the human body comes from our mitochondrial nano engines which take electrons from our food (ultimately light) and use them to generate an electrochemical potential utilizing hydrogen ions with ATPase which in turn makes ATP, (the molecule that our body can use to do work.)

The photonic energy from the sun is converted into matter and stored in chemical bonds (E=mc^2) utilizing photosynthesis and the photoelectric effect. Whether we eat plants or animals, they are the byproduct of light energy begin converted into matter.

The dominant spectra of light emitted from the Sun in terms of energy is around 52 to 55 percent infrared (above 700 nm), 42 to 43 percent visible (400 to 700 nm), and 3 to 5 percent ultraviolet (below 400 nm).

ALL life on earth evolved in a diurnal cycle of life in this emission spectra (excluding deep marine life utilizing heat from the earths core for its energy source).

quotedObject.fullText:
The Link Between Mitochondria & Oxidative Stress:

Warning: This is a detailed dive into the inner workings of the mitochondrion, probably only for those who are really interested. 

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are produced as a toxic by-product of ATP synthesis. They have their role in mitochondrial and cellular signalling, but can produce a shitstorm if present in excess. Most chronic, neolithic disease could be attributed to oxidative stress damaging mtDNA. 

Turns out, our magical but mischievous symbiont bacteria are the cheeky buggers producing these ROS. Mitochondria are the main generators of endogenous ROS within the cell. 

Let's take a look at how this happens. 

When the ETC is stalled or there is an excess of calories and the complexes hold their electrons for extended periods of time, ROS production increases. 

Electrons can be donated from electron carriers directly to oxygen to produce superoxide which is converted to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) by Mn/Cu/ZnSOD.

H2O2 is more stable than O2- and is capable of diffusing out of the mitochondrion into the cytosol. Glutathione peroxidase or catalse can then convert H2O2 to water. 

However, in the presence of transition metals, H2O2 can convert to hydroxyl radicals which are highly unstable. No bueno. This makes the iron-sulfur cores of mitochondrial enzymes and mitochondria in general vulnerable to ROS oxidation.

In states of caloric abundance or the absence of exercise, the proton gradient becomes hyperpolarized which stalls out the ETC.  Oxidative phosphorylating is a unidirectional system and so if one step is blocked, all steps prior are also impaired. 

 The more tightly coupled mitochondria are, the more susceptible the ETC is to stalling out in this way because protons are unable to leak out into the matrix (which would depolarize the gradient).

As the ETC stalls, the electron carriers are maximally occupied with electrons (reduced). These electrons then transfer to O2 to produce ROS. 

Exercise regenerates ADP as ATP is utilized, allowing the ATP synthase to turn once more and the proton gradient to depolarize. This resumes the flow of electrons through the ETC to restore the electrochemical gradient. In this way, electron carriers remain relatively oxidized and do not retain electrons for long. Low electron density of the ETC limits ROS production and subsequent oxidative stress. 

The uncoupling of mitochondria can have a similar effect by leaking protons into the matrix regardless of ATP synthase function.

Many scientists will want to blame the microbiome changes as the cause of the diseases. Still, they often fail to recognize how mitochondria have their own network of bacterial genomes working inside of our cells to work or fail to release massive amounts of light for signaling compared to eukaryotic cells!!!!!

We are 20% protein, 60% water, and 20% fat mass that is filled with visual & non-visual photoreceptors. Mitochondria and bacteria respond differently to this set of ‚Äúenvironmental affairs‚Äù tied to light, ¬†and I believe it explains why 21st-century diseases really exist.
